text:
Hey Mo, apologies for the delay! I have been looking into it all.
So the company director here stems from that kind of background. He's more of a modeller than an animator, but he had several years working freelance for companies and gained contacts before striking out on his own. I can get more of a story from him if you would like.
I know in some situations they made companies out of necessity, as they could not move to the job, and achieved success by finding gaps in the market.

So I had a quick look at third floor's applications for previs animators, and this is their recommendations:
"-Possesses a strong sense of composition, color, animation timing, and storytelling
-Animates a wide variety of subject matter from vehicles to small objects, to realistic character performances, all with a strong sense of camera animation
-Uses lights efficiently
-Has good knowledge of cinematic language, camera terminology and the ability to use motion blur, depth of field and other effects, to create realism
-Has the ability to clean up & accentuate mocap animation
Is team oriented and able to successfully take direction from a supervisor
-Is adaptable, flexible and accepting of change, often tossing out ideas and starting anew"

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CHdzXECbH4w> this is one of their latest reels.

Have you heard of flooby nooby? While most of his posts, like this one <http://www.floobynooby.com/comp1.html> , talk about 2D aspects of cinematography, there are also posts about CG, like this post <http://floobynooby.blogspot.com/2013/12/the-cinematography-of-incredibles-part-1.html> which I find incredibly insightful for constructing a shot.

To be honest, most of the people I know who went into previs, were recommended into the position by people they knew. Which does tend to happen within the animation industry. I shall keep an eye out for any recruitment drives for you to make more of those contacts.

I also highly recommend you find demo reels from people who are working in companies like 'the third floor' and see what kind of showreels they were applying with.
